conclusion: Trying to solve problem about concealed lock in self-locking state; need to find normal force between latch and lock groove.
Diagram shows housing A, frame B, spring C, latch D with angle θ = 30°, lock groove E, connecting rods, and lock heads.
Figure A shows lock in initial state; Figure B shows self-locking state with spring compressed by distance x; contact point is P.
Dynamic friction coefficient is μ; maximum static friction force is F_fm = μF_N, where F_N is normal force.
Need to find magnitude of normal force between latch D and lock groove E when self-locking occurs.
Consider forces acting on latch D at point P: spring force kx, normal force N, friction forces, and applied force F.
In self-locking state, forces must be in equilibrium; sum of forces in any direction should be zero.
Spring force kx acts to the left; normal force N is perpendicular to surface at P, at angle θ = 30°.
Friction force F_f is along surface at P, opposing direction of spring force's component along surface.
Spring force pushes latch to left; lock groove resists movement; friction force acts down along surface to prevent motion.
Latch is pushed by spring force kx to left, constrained by lock groove at angle θ = 30°.
Resolve spring force into components: perpendicular component is kx * sin(θ), parallel component is kx * cos(θ).
Normal force N equals perpendicular component of spring force, so N = kx * sin(θ).
Set up coordinate system aligned with surface: x'-axis parallel, y'-axis perpendicular.
In x' direction, force kx * cos(θ) tries to move latch up surface; in y' direction, force kx * sin(θ) balanced by normal force N.
